The man some social arbiters credit (or blame) for igniting the sexual revolution gets lively sometimes funny and inevitably provocative biopic treatment in "Kinsey." More upfront about sex both verbally and visually than anything usually expected from an R-rated studio-affiliated star-laden feature Bill Condons first directorial outing since "Gods and Monsters" provides a bracing sense of the pervasive ignorance and avoidance of sexual information that made Alfred Kinseys pioneering research such a bombshell in post-war America. Pics subject matter and very breezy approach to it will make this a hot want-see with sophisticated audiences and the more controversy it generates in the popular media the better B.O. will be for this Fox Searchlight release upon its Nov. 12 opening. A Harvard-trained zoologist with an esoteric specialty in gall wasps Kinsey was a middle-aged biology professor at the Indiana U when questions from his students made him realize how little was actually known and documented about sex and sexual practices. He started changing that with a frank "marriage" course at school and ultimately embarked upon an enormous research project that involved interviewing thousands of people nationwide about their detailed sexual histories. When the first fruits of his labors were published in 1948 as "Sexual Behavior in the Human Male" the book became a huge bestseller as well as a cultural flashpoint. With information that nonjudgmentally revealed far more pre-marital extramarital and homosexual activity in the populace than anyone would have suspected the book both astonished and outraged with some even smelling a Communist plot to break down the fabric of American culture. When his study of females appeared five years later statistics -- such as those indicating that nearly 50 per cent of women had premarital sex -- insured even greater wrath. "Kinsey" is good at portraying the socially upright backdrop for the doctors unpremeditated subversion while also making clear that the nation was nowhere near as square as simplistic portraits might suggest. In deft strokes the picture illustrates how Kinseys personality was importantly forged in reaction to his impossibly demanding Methodist Sunday School teacher father (John Lithgow) and how his obsessive interest in tiny insects made him an unlikely candidate to become a sexual pioneer or even a husband. That changes when at Indiana Kinsey (Liam Neesom) meets Clara McMillen (Laura Linney) an equally brainy student whos aggressive and attractive enough to get him to look up from the microscope. Film loosens the audience up and prepares it for much to come with the couples mutual confession of virginity on their wedding night (Kinsey was 26) and with the frank and funny treatment of their sexual incompatibility resulting from Kinsey being too big for his bride a problem that could only be solved surgically. After that theyre as busy as bunnies. Kinseys scientific interest in human sexuality begins when students begin coming to him with questions he cant answer and for which he realizes there is no documentation. Books written for young marrieds are fairy tales loaded with info and advice thats misleading at best and terribly damaging at worst. This leads him in 1938 to teach the marriage class which instead of pussyfooting around what happens in the sack gets down to the nitty-gritty with a bluntness that initially shocks and embarrasses students unaccustomed to seeing projected photos of male and female genitalia but also creates SRO crowds. Kinseys adventurous methods attract campus critics as well as acolytes and among the latter is a small group of earnest enthusiastic young men to whom he begins teaching proper interrogation techniques to collect sexual data. These interviews scattered throughout the film are cheerfully straightforward and uncensored an attitude made manifest in a nifty little montage sequence in which a few talking heads multiply into dozens and more across a map of the United States covered with faces happily nattering on about their sex lives. Tale of a door being opened to a long-locked room takes an unexpected turn when Kinsey ventures to Chicago with his closest young associate Clyde Martin (Peter Sarsgaard) to interview men in a gay bar. Sessions go so well that once in their hotel room a nude Clyde propositions his boss and mentor which in turn leads to funny/sad confessions to Clara and a subsequent table-turning on Kinsey as well as much speculation on what per cent gay or straight bisexuals can be. Account extends to the "swinging" that Kinsey encourages in his proteges who also include Wardell Pomeroy (Chris ODonnell) and Paul Gebhard (Timothy Hutton) and their wives/girlfriends but the sweep of Condons screenplay simply doesnt leave enough time to deal with this satisfactorily; one gets the unsurprising impression that the men were far more enthusiastic about the idea than were the women but no more. With success as revolutionary as Kinseys comes notoriety and with notoriety comes unwanted attention from the likes of the FBI and political high-grounders. Criticism of "Sexual Behavior in the Human Female" results in the withdrawal of funding from the Rockefeller Foundation and the more Kinsey is forced into the role of crusader due to his victimization the less interesting and distinctive he becomes as a dramatic figure. Apparently exhausted and overstressed the normally tireless Kinsey died of a heart attack in 1956 at 62. For most of the way though "Kinsey" is an interesting life story told in a fun disarming way. Charging through a superficially reticent world like an intelligent bull Neeson makes Kinsey into a force of nature a properly raised late-blooming hedonist for whom no sexual act is unnatural and whose first commandment to his interviewers is "Never make judgments about people." Adorned like the real man with an unruly thatch of wheat-like hair Neeson gives his character a vigorous reading whose humorousness often stems from his self-involved obliviousness. Linney marvelously conveys the diverse qualities that make Clara a woman able to cope with such a man one whose behavior demands even greater flexibility and understanding as the years go on. Linneys Clara is crucially a salt of the earth character specifically the Indiana earth of 100 years ago that could take bitter cold and brutal heat and still be highly fertile. Supporting turns are convincing and uniformly energized. Striking cameos are provided by William Sadler as an aging sexual gourmand and deviant proud to illuminate a lifetime of sexual adventuring for Kinseys delectation and Lynn Redgrave as a woman whose desire to thank Kinsey for helping her navigate a mid-life change in sexual orientation gives the film a warmly human albeit perhaps too self-consciously calculated a capper. Frederick Elmes boldly colorful widescreen lensing combines with Richard Shermans production design and Bruce Finlaysons costumes to provide a half-centurys worth of period feel while Carter Burwells strong score contains evocative strains of musical Americana.
